answers.text: @zuagroastebayrischeschwaebin Ah!

@_static.sound Yes, I know. But that sort of nickname is in England quite common, they do it with many names, never heard it in Germany or Austria though, so I thought it might have come from speaking English together.

@kleinste_baerin at least â€Sofferlâ€œ is a quite common nickname in Bavaria/South Germany. I read that Sophie was also called this way, even with a neutral article (â€šdas Sofferâ€˜) because of her masculine behavior/not-girly-like behavior. Iâ€˜m not sure why they missed out the â€lâ€œ â€¦ maybe also to emphasize the â€šmasculinityâ€˜?
@kleinste_baerin it's a nickname

@kleinste_baerin #TeamSoffer Sophieâ€™s nickname among her closest family and friends was â€œSofferâ€ or â€œDer Sofferâ€. Thereâ€™s no evidence that her name comes from another country. Itâ€™s believed that the nickname is inspired by the fact that Sophie was described as not very girly, but rather boyish, bold and lively (see Gottschalk, p. 70).
